Comment: I love getting feedback from the community here and so I thought I'd share this game because I won it and only 1 exchange of pawns happened in it.
Rare I that I face d5 when I play e4

So this affords to spare you guys another of my bishops opening games. I always like to reply with e5. As a nimso player as black I really hate the discomfort of this pawn and so I don't hold back to use it when I can as white hehe.
Opponent replies with c5. First time I face this.
I still reply with d4.
Personally I think I would've done cxd4 to gain some time on queen retake with 4.Qxd4 Nc6. But he opted with e6.
I always love c3 as white and this will keep middle solid.
Opts for the exchange now.
Hmm blocks in dsb looks like my opponent is either cramping himself or looking for a Qside battle
Hmm blocks in dsb looks like my opponent is either cramping himself or looking for a Qside battle
I love this spot for lsb set to attack on his king side castle. Don't need to help him develop with a Bb5+
Hmm moves same knight again I guess my assumption of him wanting to fight qside was right.
Defend d pawn + development.
My opponent likes the bishop check contrary to me.
I often choose to block with knight in hopes of forcing a bishop for knight exchange in a near future
Passive move since my lsb is already developed and I plan on not budging my knight.
Sorta passive reply on my part but in the hopes of getting the wanted exchange.
Does not bite.
Further development heading to castle. Is nf3 a preference call? Or is ne2 preferable keeping a possibility on moving the f pawn if wanted in a near future?
Develops his other knight looking at my opponents position I find him really cramped and I'm almost ready to strike
Mutual castlings.
Mutual castlings.
